profileText: A Senator from Oklahoma; born near Embry, Webster County, Miss., December 10, 1870; lost the sight of both eyes as a boy; attended the public schools; graduated from the normal school at Walthall, Miss., in 1890; taught school in 1890 and 1891; graduated from the law department of Cumberland University, Lebanon, Tenn., in 1892; admitted to the bar in 1892 and commenced practice in Walthall, Miss.; moved to Corsicana, Tex., in 1895; unsuccessful Populist candidate for election in 1898 to the Fifty-sixth Congress; moved to Lawton, Okla., in 1901 and continued the practice of law; member, Territorial council 1903-1905; upon the admission of Oklahoma as a State into the Union was elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate for the term ending March 3, 1909; reelected in 1908 and again in 1914 and served from December 11, 1907, to March 3, 1921; unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1920; chairman, Committee on Railroads (Sixty-second Congress), Committee on Agriculture and Forestry (Sixty-third through Sixty-fifth Congresses), Committee on Expenditures in the Department of Justice (Sixty-sixth Congress); member of the Democratic National Committee 1912-1916; appointed by President Woodrow Wilson in 1913 as a member of the Commission to Investigate and Study Rural Credits and Agricultural Cooperative Organizations in European Countries; again elected to the United States Senate in 1930 and served from March 4, 1931, to January 3, 1937; unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1936; chairman, Committee on Interoceanic Canals (Seventy-third and Seventy-fourth Congresses); practiced law in Washington, D.C., until his death on March 16, 1949; initially interred at Rosehill Cemetery, Oklahoma City, Okla; reinterred on July 19, 1949 in Fairlawn Cemetery in Oklahoma City.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Billington, Monroe. "Senator Thomas P. Gore.'' Chronicles of Oklahoma 35 (Autumn 1957): 265-87.
___. "Senator Thomas P. Gore: Southern Isolationist.'' Southwestern Social Science Quarterly 42 (March 1962): 381-89.
___. Thomas P. Gore: The Blind Senator From Oklahoma. Lawrence: University of Kansas Press, 1967.
___. "Thomas P. Gore and Oklahoma Public Opinion, 1917-1918.''Journal of Southern History 27 (August 1961): 344-53.
___, ed. "An Unmailed Letter from Senator Thomas P. Gore to Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes.'' Chronicles of Oklahoma 32 (Winter 1954-1955): 429-30.
Gore, Thomas P. "The Foreign Policy of the United States.'' Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science 54 (July 1914): 277-81.
___. "The True Basis for America's World Influence.'' Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science 66 (July 1916): 130-35.
McDonald, Timothy G. "The Gore-McLemore Resolutions: Democratic Revolt against Wilson's Submarine Policy.'' Historian 26 (November 1963): 50-74.
Travis, Paul D. "Gore, Bristow and Taft.'' Chronicles of Oklahoma 53 (Summer 1975): 212-24.

1882. 1 item. Memoir written while serving as a page in the Mississippi legislature.

researchRecord.name: 2 boxes of Thomas Gore papers in Gore Vidal papers, 1888-1892.
Correspondence in Mildred Hicks papers, 1917-1945. Finding aid.
In Winthrop Williams Aldrich papers, 1918-ca.1973. Appointment necessary to consult collection.

recordLocation.name: Graduate School of Business Administration Baker Library

researchRecord.name: 1890-1948 (bulk 1930s-1940s). 15 cubic feet. General correspondence, form letters, speeches, clippings, family records, and photographs. Topics include campaigns, national and Oklahoma politics, Indian affairs, economics, World War II, taxation, petroleum and the petroleum industry. Finding aid available on-line.

In Charles Gordon Watts papers, 1907-1944; Orel Busby papers, 1918-1959; Herbert Massey Peck papers, 1838-1961; Charles N. Haskell papers, 1863-1929; Jesse Lee Rader papers, 1901-1953; William M. Tilghman papers, 1843-1960; Charles Bismark Ames printed material, 1902-1918; Martin Luther Turner papers, 1888-1921; Patrick J. Hurley papers, 1900-1956; Walter S. Ferguson photoprints, 1870-1920; and Green McCurtain papers, 1890-1916.

recordLocation.name: Small quantity of papers in family custody; majority of papers destroyed when Gore left the Senate.
